As the title says, not sure where the issue is coming from though.
That's the viewset in the repo:
```
class UserViewSet(viewsets.ModelViewSet):
    serializer_class = settings.SERIALIZERS.user
    queryset = User.objects.all()
    permission_classes = settings.PERMISSIONS.user
    token_generator = default_token_generator
    lookup_field = settings.USER_ID_FIELD
```

And that's the viewset installed in my virtualenv
```
class UserViewSet(viewsets.ModelViewSet):

    permission_classes = settings.PERMISSIONS.user
```

items.title: When using DRF OpenAPI we can not assume a self.request is available
items.body:
```
def get_queryset(self):
    user = self.request.user
    ...
```

will fail when no request is available, which leaves OpenAPI with no way to determine the query set used.

```py
def get_queryset(self):
    if not self.request:
        return User.objects.none()
    ...
```

Fixes this for me.

# How to reproduce:
- Add OpenAPI according to DRF 3.10
- run  ./manage.py generateschema on a djoser project

You should see 

```
UserWarning: <class 'djoser.views.UserViewSet'> is not compatible with schema generation
```

See pull request #505

items.title: /auth/users/activation/ endpoint only accepts user UID, but what if i use standartd ID???
items.body:
Hello
According the source code in `/djoser/serializers.py`:

UidAndTokenSerializer , method -validate()

  ```
 def validate(self, attrs):
        validated_data = super().validate(attrs)

        # uid validation have to be here, because validate_<field_name>
        # doesn't work with modelserializer
        try:
            uid = utils.decode_uid(self.initial_data.get("uid", ""))
            self.user = User.objects.get(pk=uid)
        except (User.DoesNotExist, ValueError, TypeError, OverflowError):
            key_error = "invalid_uid"
            raise ValidationError(
                {"uid": [self.error_messages[key_error]]}, code=key_error
            )
```
It only accepts UID of user from frontend, correct? But what if i use standard integer id for user model instead of UID? It seems the only way to fix it is to  use custom serializer?

items.title: set_username endpoint ignores the current_password field
items.body:
There's no test written on the use case.

Reproduce : call the endpoint with a wrong password, or with no current_password field at all.

I've added the missing and failing test here: https://github.com/skoot/djoser/commit/9250eaef154dedebecee91b0d3f2ad785bef952e

I'm working on a solution but if someone more familiar with the codebase knows what needs to be done go ahead. :)

In the meantime, my workaround is to extend the serializer and set the fields statically:

```
class MySetUsernameSerializer(SetUsernameSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = User
        fields = ["username", "current_password"]
```

And then set the custom serializer in the settings.

items.title: user "delete" permissions and serializer settings not respected
items.body:
The permission_class setting for "user_delete" is not respected as `UserViewSet.get_permissions` doesn't check for action `delete` or (`me` with method `DELETE`). Instead, it just uses the default class permission.

Also the `UserViewSet.get_serializer_class` doesn't work for `user_delete` as the action that is checked is `remove` while the real action should be `delete`. This serializer setting is important as out-of-the-box it requires the user's password before deleting.

User Model
```python
class User(AbstractUser):
    USERNAME_FIELD = 'email'
    REQUIRED_FIELDS = []

    username = None
    email = models.EmailField('Email', unique=True)
    company = models.ForeignKey(Company, on_delete=models.CASCADE, null=True, blank=True)

    objects = IMSUserManager()
```

UserManager, rewrite without username
```python
class IMSUserManager(BaseUserManager):
    use_in_migrations = True

    def _create_user(self, email, password, **extra_fields):
        """
        Create and save a user with the given username, email, and password.
        """

        if not email:
            raise ValueError('The given email must be set')
        email = self.normalize_email(email)
        user = self.model(email=email, **extra_fields)
        user.set_password(password)
        user.save(using=self._db)

        return user

    def create_user(self, email=None, password=None, **extra_fields):
        extra_fields.setdefault('is_staff', False)
        extra_fields.setdefault('is_superuser', False)

        return self._create_user(email, password, **extra_fields)

    def create_superuser(self, email, password, **extra_fields):
        extra_fields.setdefault('is_staff', True)
        extra_fields.setdefault('is_superuser', True)

        if extra_fields.get('is_staff') is not True:
            raise ValueError('Superuser must have is_staff=True.')
        if extra_fields.get('is_superuser') is not True:
            raise ValueError('Superuser must have is_superuser=True.')

        return self._create_user(email, password, **extra_fields)
```

```
def encode_uid(pk):
    return force_text(urlsafe_base64_encode(force_bytes(pk)))

def decode_uid(pk):
    print(pk) # 583-f12783b9b4f6b70ee1a1
    print(urlsafe_base64_decode(pk)) # b'\xe7\xcd\xfe\x7f]\xbb\xf3v\xfdo\x87\xfao\xbd\x1e{V\xb5'
    print(force_text(urlsafe_base64_decode(pk))) # This is empty!!!
    return force_text(urlsafe_base64_decode(pk)) # Should return 0db8685f-fcd5-4af5-af25-c354f369c2e2
```

Added in some comments for the above process for UUIDs.

items.title: TypeError: post() got an unexpected keyword argument 'XYZ'
items.body:
Using a url scheme like this:


main.urls:
```
[...]
url(r'^apiv1/authx/(?P<XYZ>[-\w]+)/(?P<zyx>[-\w]+)/', include('authx.urls')),
[...]
```

authx.urls:
```
[...]
 url(r'^auth/', include('djoser.urls')),
[...]
```

I am getting a TypeError
```
TypeError: post() got an unexpected keyword argument 'XYZ'
```


This appears to be a direct cause of this code in DRF
https://github.com/encode/django-rest-framework/blob/master/rest_framework/views.py#L492
```
response = handler(request, *args, **kwargs)
```

which tries to call post() method with **kwargs, but the handler in djoser doesn't implement **kwargs
https://github.com/sunscrapers/djoser/blob/master/djoser/utils.py#L35
```
    def post(self, request):
```


Will you accept a PR to add **kwargs in that post() handler?

items.title: 403 error on user requests

1. Sign into a non-administrative user
2. Attempt to retrieve another user from `GET /auth/users/:userid/`

403 error.

items.title: User viewset does not support partial PATCH updates
items.body:
## Code at fault:
https://github.com/sunscrapers/djoser/blob/ab825cb57785e77c8618abaf4301a25b66b4071f/djoser/views.py#L332-L333

## Expected result:
`PATCH` requests should support partial updates (where only included fields are validated). This allows one to update, say, the `first_name` field without needing to also include/update the `username`.

Supporting partial updates over `PATCH` is standard for Django Rest Framework. See: 
- https://github.com/encode/django-rest-framework/blob/eb3d078a2cbda2d6e576cbfd773f153d1bdf5c5b/rest_framework/routers.py#L122
- https://github.com/encode/django-rest-framework/blob/eb3d078a2cbda2d6e576cbfd773f153d1bdf5c5b/rest_framework/mixins.py#L82-L84

items.title: Password reset link remains valid after usage
items.body:
The password reset link generated by `djoser.views.PasswordResetView` remains valid after use. In fact, when requesting a password reset again, the same link is sent.

This is a bit of a security risk, because anyone with that link (even if it has been years ago that you requested a password reset) can change your password. I don't think users would expect that the link remains valid after usage, and might not be as careful with it as they should be.

Of course, the current scheme has the adventage that it is stateless on the server. A link that is invalidated after use requires some information to be stored somehow. I think it would be a trade-off i'm willing to make: some database storage for improved security.

items.title: Split user serializers
items.body:
In many applications, the response from `/users/<id>/` should contain a different set of fields than the response from `/users/me/`. This could be for privacy (not allowing other users access to confidential attributes on the user model) or simply because one requires a different set of information for the current user (e.g. settings).

It is possible to work around this issue with a custom viewset, but it does not work on legacy endpoints and adds unnecessary complexity to this common use case.

I propose that the serializer configuration for users be split into the following two settings:
- `user`
- `me`

items.title: Make trailing slash optional in url routes
items.body:
[Back in 2013](https://github.com/encode/django-rest-framework/issues/905) DRF added support to optionally exclude the trailing slash from url routes. Though Django url conventions use a trailing slash, many Google tools don't work with them (Angluar, Chrome browser APIs...), and if you rely on using `APPEND_SLASH = True` in your Django settings, you lose the POST data during the redirect.

The djoser urls all have a compulsory trailing slash, but I can't use djoser with with Chrome's `fetch()` browser API, because it strips the trailing slash when making the request. At the moment I'm using a forked djoser with modified urls.

Obviously the url regex can be modified to include `[/]` at the end as an easy fix, but is it worth putting a TRAILING_SLASH setting in to gain explicit control over if it is permitted?

```python
 def validate(self, attrs):
        attrs = super(ActivationSerializer, self).validate(attrs)

```

items.title: UserAttributeSimilarityValidator does not work with djoser
items.body:
When creating a new user (and possible when changing and/or resetting an existing user's password) the password validation is called in a way that's not compatible with Django's `UserAttributeSimilarityValidator`.

The `UserAttributeSimilarityValidator` is supposed to be called with the password *and* the user instance. Djoser only supplies the password, causing the `UserAttributeSimilarityValidator` to short circuit and return early (without a warning).

Since `UserAttributeSimilarityValidator` is in the default list of password validators in recent Django projects I would've expected it to work with Djoser as well.
